subject: Re: [junit] How Junit will test all assert methods, even if one or more assert methods fails in a TestCase?
msgSnippet: Maybe you could throw in a reference to JFunc, a JUnit extension, which will give the tester the option of having multiple failures.
messageBody:
Maybe you could throw in a reference to JFunc, a JUnit extension, which
will give the tester the option of having multiple failures.

http://jfunc.sourceforge.net

-shane

On Tuesday, June 4, 2002, at 09:50 AM, Mike Clark wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>>> Hmmm, a lot of ink has been spilled on this question on this list.
>>> While I don't object to your message Alexander, I'd like to motion
>>> that we collectively refrain from reopening this discussion.
>>>
>>
>> Seconded. Let's handle this one really well in the FAQ, including all
>> opinions, and point future instances of the question to the FAQ.
>>
>
> This entry is weak in the draft FAQ right now:
>
> ----
>
> Why does JUnit only report the first failure in a single test?
>
> A single test method may contain multiple assertions, but the test
> method fails as soon as any of its assertions fail.
>
> By design, JUnit assumes there's no reason to report multiple failures
> in a given test method. Once a test fails, it can only fail more and
> clutter the output with side-effect failures.
>
> ----
>
> I intended to mention where to get the patch for collecting multiple
> failures, among other things.
>
> If anyone wants to take a shot at elaborating on this, it would be much
> appreciated! We'll all celebrate not having to continually address it.
>
> Mike
>
